javadoc:
Class that uses a single thread to execute scheduled jobs.

Subclasses provide the {@link BlockingQueue} implementation, which allows for controlling how jobs get scheduled (e.g., FIFO or priority-based).

methods.name: <init>
methods.comment: Constructs a new Worker with the given name.

params.name: queue
params.comment:
the queue into which jobs will be place.  e.g. PriorityBlockingQueue or 
              LinkedBlockingQueue

params.name: isPersistentThread
name
params.comment:
the name of this worker. The thread that executes the jobs will have this
             name.

params.name: shareThreadPool
params.comment:
true signals to use the given name to find/create a thread pool 
             that can be shared throughout the system.

params.name: monitor
params.comment: the task monitor that allows for cancelling of jobs.

methods.javadoc:
Schedules the job for execution.  Jobs will be processed in priority order.  The
 highest priority jobs are those with the lowest value return by the job's getPriority()
 method. (i.e. the job with priority 0 will be processed before the job with priority 1)
@param job the job to be executed.
methods.name: schedule
methods.comment:
Schedules the job for execution.  Jobs will be processed in priority order.  The
 highest priority jobs are those with the lowest value return by the job's getPriority()
 method. (i.e. the job with priority 0 will be processed before the job with priority 1)

methods.javadoc: Clears any pending jobs and cancels any currently executing job.
methods.name: clearAllJobs
methods.comment: Clears any pending jobs and cancels any currently executing job.

methods.javadoc:
Clears any pending jobs and cancels any currently executing job.

Warning: Calling this method may leave the program in a bad state. Thus, it is recommended that you only do so when you known that any job that could possibly be scheduled does not manipulate sensitive parts of the program; for example, opening file handles that should be closed before finishing.

If you are unsure about whether your jobs handle interrupt correctly, then don't use this method.
methods.name: clearAllJobsWithInterrupt_IKnowTheRisks
methods.comment:
Clears any pending jobs and cancels any currently executing job.
  
  Warning: Calling this method may leave the program in a bad
  state.  Thus, it is recommended that you only do so when you known that any job that
  could possibly be scheduled does not manipulate sensitive parts of the program; for 
  example, opening file handles that should be closed before finishing.  
  
  If you are unsure 
  about whether your jobs handle interrupt correctly, then don't use this method.

methods.javadoc: Clears any jobs from the queue that have not yet been run. This does not cancel the currently running job.
methods.name: clearPendingJobs
methods.comment:
Clears any jobs from the queue that have not yet been run.  This does not cancel 
 the currently running job.

methods.javadoc: Disposes this worker and terminates its thread.
methods.name: dispose
methods.comment: Disposes this worker and terminates its thread.

methods.javadoc:
This method will block until there are no scheduled jobs in this worker. This method assumes that all jobs have a priority less than Long.MAX_VALUE.

For a non-priority queue, this call will not wait for jobs that are scheduled after this call was made.
methods.name: waitUntilNoJobsScheduled
methods.comment:
This method will block until there are no scheduled jobs in this worker. This
 method assumes that all jobs have a priority less than Long.MAX_VALUE.   
 
 For a non-priority
 queue, this call will not wait for jobs that are scheduled after this call was made.

name: AbstractWorker
comment:
Class that uses a single thread to execute scheduled jobs.
 
 Subclasses provide the BlockingQueue implementation, which allows for controlling
 how jobs get scheduled (e.g., FIFO or priority-based).
